Chad Bohannan wrote:

> A more detailed example:
> a LSTM (Long Short Term Memory) is a complicated network that could 
> remember particular obsticals such as a train coming. A standard NEAT 
> might be both smaller and more efficient if it new nothing about 
> trains. It would be confident about how to deal with boulders and 
> trenches that don't move. The conventional controller would keep track 
> of remembering where to go.
> So in the particular example, the NEAT is doing a good job interacting 
> with the conventional controller and avoiding the bolders and 
> skillfully manuevering the ditches the conventional controller knows 
> nothing about, when all of a sudden, the LSTM becomes very confident 
> that death is a DARPA locomotive, and now would be a good time to 
> stop. So the LSTM confidence output goes from low to high very 
> quickly, drowning the output of the NEAT. The result is most likely to 
> stop the robot right away.
> This would work on the idea that the LSTM doesn't know where the robot 
> is going or how to avoid drowning in a river, the NEAT doesn't know 
> anything about trains, and can't remember where it's going, and the 
> conventional controller can use a GPS and ethernet, but doesn't know 
> what trains and ditches are.
> Any of that make sense?
>
Hi Chad,

Yes I think I understand. I would tend to think of the technique you 
describe as being a further level of task decomposition. I described 
braking the goal task into layers, high to low. I think the technique 
you describe would fit in nicely by taking a sub-task at a specific 
layer and braking it down further. Would you agree?

Colin.
